articles.headline: New Oil Train Rules Are Hit From All Sides
articles.snippet: The regulations will phase out older tank cars and mandate new braking technology, but some critics called the changes inadequate.
articles.abstract: The regulations will phase out older tank cars and mandate new braking technology, but some critics called the changes inadequate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ending months of uncertainty and delays, federal regulators on Friday unveiled new rules for transporting crude oil by trains, saying the measures would improve rail safety and reduce the risks of a catastrophic event.

articles.headline: UKIP Has Changed Britain’s Conversation. Now It Needs a Big Win.
articles.snippet: South Thanet on England’s southern coast has become one of the most closely watched districts as the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, Nigel Farage, tries to win a seat.
articles.abstract: South Thanet on England’s southern coast has become one of the most closely watched districts as the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, Nigel Farage, tries to win a seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMSGATE, England — As word spread that Nigel Farage was on his way for a stroll through this faded seaside town, tensions began to flare.

articles.headline: Cleveland Indians Have Home-Field Advantage on Recycling
articles.snippet: Progressive Field’s concessions adopt a system that converts food waste to energy.
articles.abstract: Progressive Field’s concessions adopt a system that converts food waste to energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Well before the start of a Cleveland Indians game at Progressive Field, as players warmed up on the jewel-green field, it was business as usual in the garage behind left field for C. L. Gholston, a dishwasher.

articles.headline: Tidal, Music Streaming Service, Seeks Footing After a Stumble
articles.snippet: Music and technology executives say that it is far too early to judge Tidal, particularly given the expected arrival of Apple’s new streaming service.
articles.abstract: Music and technology executives say that it is far too early to judge Tidal, particularly given the expected arrival of Apple’s new streaming service.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a celebrity-studded, headline-grabbing product release, Jay Z’s unveiling of Tidal was about as big as could be.

articles.headline: Why the N.S.A. Isn’t Howling Over Restrictions
articles.snippet: As Congress moves to take the government out of the business of bulk collection of domestic calling data, the National Security Agency is hardly resisting.
articles.abstract: As Congress moves to take the government out of the business of bulk collection of domestic calling data, the National Security Agency is hardly resisting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, even as the National Security Agency fiercely defended its secret efforts to sweep up domestic telephone data, there were doubters inside the agency who considered the program wildly expensive with few successes to show for it.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: F.E.C. Can’t Curb 2016 Election Abuse, Commission Chief Says
articles.snippet: There is a stalemate among the agency’s six commissioners, who are perpetually locked in 3-to-3 ties along party lines because of a fundamental disagreement over the commission’s mandate.
articles.abstract: There is a stalemate among the agency’s six commissioners, who are perpetually locked in 3-to-3 ties along party lines because of a fundamental disagreement over the commission’s mandate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leader of the Federal Election Commission, the agency charged with regulating the way political money is raised and spent, says she has largely given up hope of reining in abuses in the 2016 presidential campaign, which could generate a record $10 billion in spending.

articles.headline: Hands-Free Cars Take Wheel, and Law Isn’t Stopping Them
articles.snippet: Tesla, Volvo, Audi and Cadillac all plan to release vehicles that enable some hands-free driving within the next year, but few states have laws on the books.
articles.abstract: Tesla, Volvo, Audi and Cadillac all plan to release vehicles that enable some hands-free driving within the next year, but few states have laws on the books.
articles.lead_paragraph: A General Motors promotional film envisions the future: Drivers enter the highway, put their cars on “autopilot” and sit back as the vehicle takes over and heads for the horizon. The film’s date? 1956.

articles.headline: Hard but Hopeful Home to ‘Lot of Freddies’
articles.snippet: The neighborhood where Freddie Gray came of age has survived harrowing rates of unemployment, poor health, violent crime and incarceration.
articles.abstract: The neighborhood where Freddie Gray came of age has survived harrowing rates of unemployment, poor health, violent crime and incarceration.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The teenagers stood inside Sun Deli and Grocery, ordered iced tea and fruit punch through the bulletproof glass and casually divided the marijuana they planned to sell, unconcerned that it was broad daylight or that other people were present.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Nikita Stewart and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Start-Ups Try to Challenge Google, at Least on Mobile Search
articles.snippet: Venture capitalists, intimidated by Google search for a decade, have begun investing hundreds of millions in new search efforts for mobile phones.
articles.abstract: Venture capitalists, intimidated by Google search for a decade, have begun investing hundreds of millions in new search efforts for mobile phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Europe’s competition regulator filed antitrust charges against Google on the belief that the company’s search business had become so powerful that it was pretty much impossible to compete with. But do not tell that to Bobby Lo.

articles.headline: Dave Goldberg Was Lifelong Women’s Advocate
articles.snippet: The late chief executive of SurveyMonkey and husband of the Facebook executive Sheryl Sandberg was raised around “woman power” and was an avid supporter of female achievement.
articles.abstract: The late chief executive of SurveyMonkey and husband of the Facebook executive Sheryl Sandberg was raised around “woman power” and was an avid supporter of female achievement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as a high school student, Dave Goldberg was urging female classmates to speak up. As a young dot-com executive, he had one girlfriend after another, but fell hard for a driven friend named Sheryl Sandberg, pining after her for years. After they wed, Mr. Goldberg pushed her to negotiate hard for high compensation and arranged his schedule so that he could be home with their children when she was traveling for work.

articles.headline: China, Pursuing Strategic Interests, Builds Presence in Antarctica
articles.snippet: As China spends more on the Antarctic, and the early occupiers, the United States and Australia, face stagnant budgets, a debate rages about what China wants.
articles.abstract: As China spends more on the Antarctic, and the early occupiers, the United States and Australia, face stagnant budgets, a debate rages about what China wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOBART, Tasmania — Few places seem out of reach for China’s leader, Xi Jinping, who has traveled from European capitals to obscure Pacific and Caribbean islands in pursuit of his nation’s strategic interests.

articles.headline: Long Before British Vote, Financiers Weigh In
articles.snippet: No political party has done more for hedge funds and bankers recently than Britain’s Conservatives, and the party in turn has been well rewarded.
articles.abstract: No political party has done more for hedge funds and bankers recently than Britain’s Conservatives, and the party in turn has been well rewarded.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — No political party in Europe has done more for hedge funds and bankers in recent years than the British Conservatives.

articles.headline: Rhapsody, a Lofty Literary Journal, Perused at 39,000 Feet
articles.snippet: For its front-cabin passengers, United Airlines is turning Rhapsody into the Paris Review of the air, attracting authors like Joyce Carol Oates and Anthony Doerr.
articles.abstract: For its front-cabin passengers, United Airlines is turning Rhapsody into the Paris Review of the air, attracting authors like Joyce Carol Oates and Anthony Doerr.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer at a writers’ workshop in Oregon, the novelists Anthony Doerr, Karen Russell and Elissa Schappell were chatting over cocktails when they realized they had all published work in the same magazine. It wasn’t one of the usual literary outlets, like Tin House, The Paris Review or The New Yorker. It was Rhapsody, an in-flight magazine for United Airlines.

articles.headline: As Vice Moves More to TV, It Tries to Keep Brash Voice
articles.snippet: Vice has signed deals worth hundreds of millions of dollars with established TV companies that are eager to engage its young, male audience. But will it have to play by different rules?
articles.abstract: Vice has signed deals worth hundreds of millions of dollars with established TV companies that are eager to engage its young, male audience. But will it have to play by different rules?
articles.lead_paragraph: The live music at the Vice Media party on Friday shook the room. Shane Smith, Vice’s chief executive, was standing near the stage — with a drink in his hand, pants sagging, tattoos showing — watching the rapper-cum-chef Action Bronson make pizzas.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Campaign Coverage via Snapchat Could Shake Up the 2016 Elections
articles.snippet: The question of how the fast-growing app could shape the election arose after it hired a CNN political reporter to lead its nascent news division.
articles.abstract: The question of how the fast-growing app could shape the election arose after it hired a CNN political reporter to lead its nascent news division.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the 2008 presidential race, two online upstarts, Politico and The Huffington Post, elbowed their way onto the rope line and, for better or for worse, helped change the way campaigns were covered. In 2012, it was BuzzFeed’s turn. The site that specialized in cute kittens and funny lists turned up at the Iowa caucuses and sped up the news cycle even further, flooding Twitter feeds with tidbits from the trail.

articles.headline: The Uphill Battle to Better Regulate Formaldehyde
articles.snippet: E.P.A. rules aim to address dangerous fumes from the chemical, often used in furniture, but industry forces and others see government overreach.
articles.abstract: E.P.A. rules aim to address dangerous fumes from the chemical, often used in furniture, but industry forces and others see government overreach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A decade after emergency trailers meant to shelter Hurricane Katrina victims instead caused burning eyes, sore throats and other more serious ailments, the Environmental Protection Agency is on the verge of regulating the culprit: formaldehyde, a chemical that can be found in commonplace things like clothes and furniture.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: G.O.P. Hopefuls Now Aiming to Woo the Middle Class
articles.snippet: The candidates who hope to be the Republican presidential nominee in 2016 are trying to create a very different set of associations than the last three.
articles.abstract: The candidates who hope to be the Republican presidential nominee in 2016 are trying to create a very different set of associations than the last three.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last three men to win the Republican nomination have been the prosperous son of a president (George W. Bush), a senator who could not recall how many homes his family owned (John McCain of Arizona; it was seven) and a private equity executive worth an estimated $200 million (Mitt Romney).

articles.headline: Odd Push in Drug-Averse Norway: LSD Is O.K.
articles.snippet: An advocacy group wants to manufacture psychedelic drugs to prove they are safe and beneficial, part of a global movement to revise drug policies.
articles.abstract: An advocacy group wants to manufacture psychedelic drugs to prove they are safe and beneficial, part of a global movement to revise drug policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO — In a country so wary of drug abuse that it limits the sale of aspirin, Pal-Orjan Johansen, a Norwegian researcher, is pushing what would seem a doomed cause: the rehabilitation of LSD.

articles.headline: Obama Finds a Bolder Voice on Race Issues
articles.snippet: President Obama seems to be focusing on the plight of young black and Latino men as he thinks about his remaining time in office and beyond.
articles.abstract: President Obama seems to be focusing on the plight of young black and Latino men as he thinks about his remaining time in office and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he reflected on the festering wounds deepened by race and grievance that have been on painful display in America’s cities lately, President Obama on Monday found himself thinking about a young man he had just met named Malachi.

articles.headline: John Chambers Steps Aside at Cisco as Generational Shift Arrives
articles.snippet: Mr. Chambers, one of the longest-serving chiefs of a public Silicon Valley company, will step down on July 26.
articles.abstract: Mr. Chambers, one of the longest-serving chiefs of a public Silicon Valley company, will step down on July 26.
articles.lead_paragraph: Technology’s older generation of rebels has now almost completely disrupted itself.

articles.headline: Gunman in Texas Shooting Was F.B.I. Suspect in Jihad Inquiry
articles.snippet: One of the two men who were killed after they opened fire at a gathering in Garland, Tex., was charged with plotting “violent jihad” in Somalia.
articles.abstract: One of the two men who were killed after they opened fire at a gathering in Garland, Tex., was charged with plotting “violent jihad” in Somalia.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARLAND, Tex. — One was an extrovert drawn to basketball as well as to Islam, who had been identified by the F.B.I. as a jihadist terrorism suspect and was once a regular at Friday Prayer at a mosque near his Phoenix apartment. The other was more quiet, ran a carpet cleaning business in Phoenix and often prayed at the same mosque, sometimes accompanied by his young son.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Richard Pérez-Peña and Fernanda Santos
